title: Proptech start-up secures Andrew Bogut slam dunk
text:
Mr Bogut, a seasoned investor in both residential and commercial property, said he liked the idea because of its potential to save advertising costs and reduce the amount of time spent searching for properties.

"You're not getting rid of estate agents, but it's a different avenue for people to buy and sell," he said.

Speaking of his own experiences, he said: "Signing a marketing contract with an agent can be a waste of money. As soon as they get the bottom line, service goes out the window."

As an investor who often bought off-market, he said he liked the idea of being "hit up" as soon as a listing matched your criteria and budget.

Mr Bogut said he would promote Listing Loop through his sporting contacts – this year the NBA veteran is playing locally for the Sydney Kings – and also through social media "where I get a bit of attention".

Mr Dallwitz said the idea behind Listing Loop was to centralise off-market listings so buyers had access to offerings across all agencies.

"Currently, to get pre-market listings, you have to ring up each agency and get added to their databases. There's a lot of system breakdown because agents don't have a system to manage off-market sales," he said.

Mr Dallwitz said Listing Loop was not trying to be an REA or Domain, which he called "fantastic businesses", but said his own research had identified that between 10 and 30 per cent of sales in the inner city were done off-market.

Advertisement

"Sellers are keen to sell, but upfront marketing costs are a big overhead. For some, it's a question of where do they find $5000 to $10,000," he said.

More than 650 estate agents have signed up to the Listing Loop platform, he said.

Its main competitor is another off-market matching platform, Property Whispers, which allows vendors to list property themselves for $49, or through an agent.
